intro: Trichosalpinx blaisdellii, commonly known as the Blaisdell's spider orchid, is a rare and striking member of the Orchidaceae family native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its intricate, spider-like flower structure with long, slender petals and a distinctive, twisted column. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded habitats such as pine flatwoods and wetlands, preferring well-drained, acidic soils. Its blooming period occurs in late spring to early summer, producing delicate, violet to purple flowers that attract specific pollinators. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a conservation concern.
